entry.et: Middle English glorie, from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, from Latin gloria

def.dt: :praise, honor, or distinction extended by common consent :renown
:worshipful praise, honor, and thanksgiving giving glory to God
:something that secures praise or renown the glory of a brilliant career
:great beauty and splendor :magnificence the glory that was Greece and the grandeur that was Rome E. A. Poe
:something marked by beauty or resplendence a perfect glory of a day
:the splendor and beatific happiness of heaven
:a state of great gratification or exaltation when she's acting she's in her glory
:a ring or spot of light: as
:a halo appearing around the shadow of an object

dt.un: used to express surprise or delight

def.dt: :any of a genus (Chionodoxa) of hardy spring-flowering chiefly Mediterranean bulbous herbs of the lily family with basal leaves and racemes of blue, white, or pink flowers
:any of various usually twining plants (genus Ipomoea of the family Convolvulaceae, the morning-glory family) with showy trumpet-shaped flowers
:an herb, shrub, or tree of the morning-glory family
